I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  During the Fact-Finding Mission of the Gansu Heihe Rural Hydropower Development 
Investment Program in July 2006, the Gansu provincial government (GPG) asked the Asian 
Development  Bank  (ADB)  to  provide  further  assistance  for  accelerated  development  of 
renewable energy in Gansu, with a focus on rural clean energy development. During the 2006 
Country  Programming  Mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (the 
Government) formally requested inclusion of a technical assistance (TA) in the 2007 country 
program. The TA1 was discussed with the GPG and the Government and the TA was included 
for assistance under the Second Danish Cooperation Fund for Renewable Energy and Energy 
Efficiency in Rural Areas. The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  Sustained economic growth in the People’s Republic of China (PRC) is fueling demand 
for  energy.  In  2006,  primary  energy  consumption  increased  by  9.3%  compared  with  the 
previous year to 2.46 billion tons of standard coal equivalent. Coal is the dominant source of 
primary energy, accounting for about 68.5% of total energy production in 2006. In the electricity 
subsector  in  2006  consumption  increased  by  13.4%  compared  to  the  previous  year  to                
2,834 terawatt-hours (TWh), with coal-fired power plants contributing more than 83% of the total. 
The electricity sector is the major consumer of coal; in 2006 it used about 55% of total coal 
production, which that year reached 2.38 billion tons. Economic growth is expected to continue 
at an average of about 8% for the next 5–10 years. The energy sector is expected to continue to 
grow with the economy. Despite impressive growth and achievements, the energy sector and 
the electricity subsector face many challenges, which include the following.   
 
(i)  Unbalanced energy mix with increasing dependence on coal. The PRC is 
the world’s largest producer and consumer of coal; production has more than 
doubled in the last 5 years. Increasing coal consumption has resulted in local, 
regional and global environmental problems. About 90% of sulfur dioxide,85% of 
 
carbon dioxide,67% of nitrogen oxide, and 80% of total fly ash emissions into the 
 
atmosphere are due to coal burning. Acid rain falls on 40% of the total farmland.  
(ii)  High energy intensity.2 Owing to high economic growth, energy intensity has 
been  increasing  since  2002.  Energy  efficiency  in  major  energy-consuming 
industries is much lower than international best practice.  
(iii)  Power  shortages.  Since 2001, the PRC has been facing power shortages, 
although these are likely to be overcome by the end of 2007 through increased 
coal-fired power capacity. However, the greater challenge is to generate the 
power needed to quadruple the size of the economy by 2020. 
(iv)  Unreliable  power  supply  to  rural  areas. About 98% of the population has 
access to electricity. Nevertheless, about 26 million people have no access. 
Supply is often unreliable and of poor quality in rural areas located at the end of 
the distribution network.  
(v)  Sub-optimal use of rural biomass energy sources. Large-scale agriculture is 
accompanied by large agro-based biomass, which is a clean-energy source for 
rural energy needs. However, agriculture biomass is often used inefficiently, or 
simply burnt, thus causing further environmental problems.

3.  The  11th  Five-Year  Plan  2006–2010  (11FYP)  aims  for  a  resource-effective  and 
environment-friendly  society.  It  emphasizes  energy  efficiency  and  sets  a  target  of  a  20% 
reduction in energy intensity to achieve the overall goal of quadrupling the economy by 2020, 
while only doubling energy consumption. The Energy Conservation Law is being modified to 
reflect these Government priorities and to strengthen regulatory measures in order to promote 
energy efficiency. The 11FYP also aims for a more diversified energy production mix with less 
dependence on coal, reducing the contribution of coal to 66%. The Renewable Energy Law was 
enacted  in  2006  to  accelerate  renewable  energy  development.  Regulations  on  tariffs  and 
access  to  the  electricity  grid  were  issued  in  2006–2007.  The  development  of  local  and 
distributed energy sources to provide access to electricity and meet rural energy needs is a key 
development priority in building a harmonious society and promoting rural development in an 
environmentally sustainable manner. The development of renewable energy sources is one of 
the four energy priorities in the 11FYP. Small- and medium-sized hydropower development has 
been a core priority in expanding renewable energy. The 11FYP specifically targets accelerated 
development of wind power sources to achieve additional capacity of 5 gigawatt (GW) and 
biomass power sources to add 5.5 GW. 
 
4.  Like  many  other  provinces,  Gansu  has  achieved  more  than  9.5%  average  gross 
domestic product (GDP) growth in the last 3 years; electricity demand has grown by an average 
of 12% a year during the same period. This rapid growth in demand has been met mostly by 
addition of coal-fired power plants, which provided about 78.5% of electricity generation in 2006. 
In addition to the heavy dependence on coal, the energy intensity levels in Gansu are also 
higher than the national average. A combination of coal combustion and desertification causes 
poor air quality; 13 of Gansu’s 14 cities do not meet acceptable standards. In rural areas, 
household energy needs are primarily met by coal (40%), and stalk and firewood combustion 
(50%), which is polluting and inefficient. Total rural energy consumption in Gansu was about  
8.6 million tons of standard coal in 2006. This is an average of about 398 kg per capita, which is 
only 70% of the national average and lower than the level needed to meet the basic energy 
needs. Owing to its geographic location and harsh climate, Gansu faces unique challenges in 
meeting the energy needs of its rural population. About one third of the rural population lives in 
areas  with  significant  energy  shortages.  To  meet  its  growing  energy  needs  in  an 
environmentally sustainable manner, the GPG has identified promotion of clean and renewable 
energy—wind, hydropower and biomass—as a key priority in the 11FYP.  
 
5.  Biomass energy is widely distributed throughout the province and provides an excellent 
local energy source to meet rural needs. The GPG has promoted integrated rural energy 
resource  development  and  launched  297  demonstration  projects  in  the  10FYP;  another                
300 demonstration projects will be implemented in the 11FYP. However, new approaches and 
technologies, together with innovative financing, need to be piloted for effective demonstration 
and  large-scale  replication.  The  GPG  has  also  successfully  installed  gasifiers  in                        
2,300 households, and biogas digesters in 181,000 households (5% of rural households). The 
GPG  aims  to  further  increase  biomass  energy  development  but  faces  the  challenges  of                   
(i)  limited  investments,  (ii)  old  and  inefficient  technology,  (iii)  lack  of  awareness,  and                      
(iv) inadequate institutional capacity.  
 
6.  Hydropower development has been steadily progressing but most of the unexploited 
hydropower resources are in medium-sized hydropower plants that are remote to the load 
centers and so face implementation difficulties. The GPG is actively seeking private sector 
participation  in  hydropower  resource  development  and  has  a  structured  plan  to  increase 
hydropower production.

3
7.  Gansu is rich in wind power resources3 and has launched initiatives to exploit this. 
Through preliminary investigation and wind data measurements, GPG has identified about              
17 priority wind power sites. It aims to set up 1 GW of wind power capacity during the 11FYP. 
About 300 megawatt (MW) of generating capacity is in the initial stages of construction. The 
GPG aims to accelerate wind power development through comprehensive medium-term plan 
but it faces (i) limited financing, (ii) inadequate preparatory activities that may delay project 
implementation, and (iii) lack of accurate wind data. There is a need to increase the planning, 
preparation, monitoring and control of the GPG’s wind power development.  
 
8.  The promotion of clean energy sources and improvement of energy efficiency are ADB’s 
strategic priorities in the sector. At the national level, ADB is assisting the Ministry of Agriculture 
in  developing  a  national  strategy  for  rural  biomass  energy  development.4 ADB  has  been 
supporting Gansu province since 2002 to develop renewable energy sources to accelerate and 
promote  rural  growth.  This  includes  support  for  the  Heihe  river  cascade  hydropower 
development in Gansu, and successful pilot testing of an integrated 200 kW stalk gasifier and 
power generation plant in Qidian village of Zhangye city under a TA.5 This current TA is a logical 
next  step  in  ADB’s  assistance  to  Gansu  province.  It  will  allow  for  sustainable  economic 
development through promotion of clean and renewable energy. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
9.  The impact of the TA will be increased use of clean energy in rural areas of Gansu. The 
outcome of the TA will be enhanced capacity in planning and management of clean energy 
development in Gansu.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
10.  The outputs of the TA include (i) mapping of clean energy resources and a renewable 
energy development plan (REDP) 2008–2012 for Gansu; (ii) identification and prefeasibility 
studies  for  priority  clean  energy  investment  projects6 for  implementation;  (iii)  identification, 
preparation, and implementation of pilot biomass energy projects; (iv) capacity assessment and 
strengthening of provincial and local agencies in clean energy planning and management; and 
(v) a publicity campaign to promote awareness of clean energy use and energy conservation in 
rural areas. 
 
11.  Close coordination with the GPG will be maintained during implementation of the TA to 
ensure that it takes into account previous studies, government priorities, existing plans, and 
results of pilot tests. Experts from the Ministry of Agriculture, Gansu Provincial Development 
and Reforms Commission (GPDRC), Gansu Provincial Department of Agriculture and Animal 
Husbandry (GPDAAH), and research institutes will be consulted to (i) aid understanding of 
current practices, priorities, and plans; and (ii) identify a suitable medium-term plan for the

12.  The  consultant  recruited  for  the  TA  will  examine  international  best  practices  and 
methods that can be used in the preparation of the REDP, summarize the features of the REDP 
and make recommendations. The essential and desirable features of the REDP will be listed at 
an early stage and a consensus will be built around these. When a preliminary structure and 
outline of the REDP is available, consultants will use the information from the demonstration 
and pilot projects to further refine and develop the REDP. A knowledge dissemination program 
will be implemented before the TA is closed.  
 
13.  The major assumptions in relation to the successful implementation of the TA include 
(i) continued emphasis on renewable energy and rural development, (ii) significant participation 
by counterpart staff, (iii) adequate and timely provision of data, and (iv) active participation in the 
consultation workshops and seminars. Since the REDP will be a medium-term plan extending 
beyond  the  11FYP,  the  risk  is  that  it  may  take  considerable  time  and  effort  to  achieve 
consensus  on  its  design.  The  GPG  is  fully  committed  to  promoting  rapid  development  of 
renewable energy, especially to meet rural energy needs. GPDAAH and GPDRC have been 
closely involved in the development of policies and guidelines at the provincial level. Close 
coordination among the consultants, GPG, GPDAAH, and ADB will be maintained during the 
implementation of the TA. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The  total  cost  of  the  TA  will  be  $1,000,000  equivalent,  of  which  $800,000  will  be 
financed on a grant basis by the Government of Denmark. This grant of $800,000 will be 
administered by ADB. The Government will finance the remaining $200,000 through in-kind 
contribution, including office accommodation and support facilities,7 counterpart staff and data 
and other necessary information. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The  GPG  will  be  the  Executing  Agency  (EA)  for  the  TA;  GPDAAH  will  be  the 
Implementing  Agency  (IA),  responsible  for  day-to-day  implementation  of  the  TA  activities. 
GPDAAH  has  already  created  a  project  management  office  at  Lanzhou  for  the  TA 
implementation. This office includes staff from the GPDRC to support the activities related to 
wind power.  
 
16.  The TA will be supervised by Gansu Province Foreign Loan Administration Committee 
(the committee), which is already established in the province. The committee will interact closely 
with the consultants and the IA during implementation of the TA. The EA will also submit regular 
reports of the progress of the TA implementation to the committee and seek its guidance as 
required.  
 
17.  ADB will engage international and national consultants, according to its Guidelines on 
the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to time). A simplified technical proposal 
will be requested by ADB and consultants will be recruited using the quality- and cost-based

selection method with quality-cost ratio of 80:20. An estimated total of 40 person-months of 
consulting  services  will  be  required:  10  person-months  for  international  consultants  and                
30  person-months  for  national  consultants.  The  following  international  consultants  will  be 
required: (i) rural biomass energy expert and team leader, (ii) wind power expert, (iii) energy 
economist, and (iv) financial analyst. The following national consultants will be required: (i) two 
rural renewable energy specialists, (ii) wind power specialist, (iii) energy economist, (iv) financial 
analyst, (v) environment analyst, and (vi) social development specialist. The outline terms of 
reference for consultants are given in Appendix 3. 
 
18.  The TA will be implemented over 12 months beginning July 2007, with an expected 
completion date of end June 2008. Suitable pilot biomass energy projects that can fit within the 
TA scope will also be implemented. The consultants will be responsible for identification, design 
and  implementation  of  the  selected  pilot  projects.  An  advance  facility  will  be  provided  for 
consultant to procure the goods and works for pilot projects. The TA implementation will involve 
extensive consultations with key stakeholders. The consultants will organize regular workshops, 
seminars and conferences to progressively seek stakeholders’ views on TA recommendations. 
The consultants will submit (i) an inception report within 4 weeks, (ii) an interim report within          
12 weeks, (iii) a midterm report within 25 weeks, (iv) a draft final report within 38 weeks, and           
(v) a final report within 44 weeks of the field mobilization. A provincial level workshop will be 
organized after the submission of each progress report to seek stakeholders’ views on TA 
outputs.  
 
19.  As part of the institutional capacity development, the consultants will recommend and 
implement  training  workshops,  seminars  and  field  visits  for  local  and  provincial  staff  from 
relevant agencies. During the initial stages of the TA implementation, a national study tour to 
other  provinces  in  the  PRC  will  be  finalized.  During  the  pilot  project  selection  phase,  the 
consultants will also propose an international study tour to identify innovative approaches and 
modern  technologies  for  pilot  testing.  The  training,  seminars  and  study  tours  will  be 
administered under the TA by the consultants; an advance payment facility will be provided, 
especially for international study tours. As part of the public information campaign for intensive 
clean energy use in rural areas, brochures will be developed by the consultants in English and 
Chinese.  Local  and  provincial  workshops  and  seminars  for  disseminating  knowledge  and 
enhancing public awareness will be conducted by the IA. The TA funds for dissemination 
activities will be administered by the IA; an advance payment facility will be provided. The 
outcome of the TA will be subject to evaluation by both ADB and the Government in accordance 
with their respective evaluation policies and requirements.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
20.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 to the Government 
of the People’s Republic of China to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of 
Denmark for Gansu Rural Clean Energy Development Project, and hereby reports this action to 
the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will be implemented in consultation with relevant bodies, 
including  Gansu  Provincial  Department  for  Agriculture  and  Animal  Husbandry  (GPDAAH), 
Gansu Provincial Development and Reforms Commission (GDRC), Gansu Provincial Finance 
Bureau,  research  institutes,  and  local  government  agencies.  The  team  of  international 
consultants  (10  person-months)  will  coordinate  its  work  with  the  national  consultants                      
(30 person-months). The international consultants will have expertise in (i) rural biomass energy, 
(ii) wind power, (iii) energy economy, and (iv) financial analysis. The national consultants will 
have  expertise  similar  to  the  international  experts,  and  additionally  in  environment  impact 
analysis, and social development (two experts). The international rural biomass energy expert 
will be the team leader and will coordinate the activities of the consultant team.   
 
A.  International Consultants  
 
2.  Rural Biomass Energy Expert and Team Leader (4.5 person-months). The expert will 
undertake the following activities:  
 
(i)  Review existing information and data on biomass energy resources in Gansu. 
(ii)  Review ongoing and completed initiatives and interventions used to promote 
biomass power generation in other provinces or nationally.  
(iii)  Review the Gansu provincial government’s (GPG’s) existing 11th Five-Year Plan 
(FYP) for promotion of biomass energy resources in Gansu. 
(iv)  Review and summarize results of previous studies and initiatives. 
(v)  Undertake the strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, threats (SWOT) analysis of 
biomass power generation in Gansu. 
(vi)  In consultation with the wind power expert and other team members, identify and 
design a framework for an overall renewable energy development plan (REDP) 
2008–2012 and an aggregated biomass energy and wind power development 
plan, and seek stakeholder acceptance of the framework. 
(vii)  In consultation with the energy economist, prepare the REDP Biomass Energy, 
and  identify  capacity-strengthening  measures  needed  for  the  GPDAAH  to 
implement the plan. 
(viii)  Identify total investment needs and innovative financing approaches, and identify 
potential support from international financial institutions. 
(ix)  In close consultation with the GPG and key stakeholders, develop benchmark 
standards and selection criteria for priority investment projects and pilot projects. 
(x)  Seek stakeholder acceptance of the set of criteria, and identify and rank priority 
investment projects and pilot projects. 
(xi)  In  conjunction  with  other  team  members,  prepare  a  detailed  prefeasibility 
report—scope, costs, financing, financial viability, etc.—for selected pilot projects, 
and  prefeasibility  assessment  of  the  highest  ranked  two  or  three  priority 
investment projects. 
(xii)  Implement pilot projects and develop monitoring indicators for their evaluation. 
(xiii)  Evaluate potential carbon financing through the clean development mechanism 
(CDM) for biomass power projects. 
(xiv)  Coordinate  tasks  among  team  members  and  regularly  liaise  with  key 
stakeholders on TA implementation.  
 
3.  Wind Power Expert (2.5 person-months). The expert will support the team leader in 
relevant tasks and will undertake the following specific tasks:

10  Appendix 3 
(i)  Review existing information and data on wind power resources in Gansu and 
map wind resources for the province. 
(ii)  Review ongoing and completed initiatives and interventions used to promote 
wind power generation in other provinces or nationally.  
(iii)  Review the GPG’s existing 11FYP for promotion of wind power generation in 
Gansu. 
(iv)  Review and summarize results of previous studies and initiatives, including the 
existing GPG plan for wind resource development in the province. 
(v)  Undertake a SWOT analysis of wind power development in Gansu. 
(vi)  Closely liaise with the team leader in designing a framework for the REDP Wind 
Power (2008–2012) and seek stakeholder acceptance of the framework. 
(vii)  In consultation with the energy economist, prepare the REDP Wind Power, and 
undertake a comprehensive evaluation of major barriers to REDP Wind Power 
implementation. 
(viii)  In close consultation with the GPG and key stakeholders, develop benchmark 
standards and selection criteria for priority investment projects. 
(ix)  Seek stakeholder acceptance of the set of criteria, and identify and rank priority 
investment projects that will be included in the REDP. 
(x)  Evaluate the available wind power data on selected priority investment projects 
(2008–2010)  and  prepare  detailed  terms  of  reference  for  verification  and 
validation of wind resource data at selected priority project sites. 
(xi)  Assist the team leader in the selection of a reputable international agency to 
carry out wind data measurement at selected priority project sites. 
(xii)  Oversee wind resource data verification at selected priority sites. 
(xiii)  In conjunction with other team members, prepare a detailed feasibility report—
scope, costs, financing, financial viability, etc.—for a selected priority investment 
project. 
(xiv)  Evaluate potential for CDM and prepare initial project definition documentation 
for a priority investment project.  
 
4.  Energy Economist (1.5 person-months). The expert will assist the team leader and 
wind power expert. In particular, the expert will undertake the following tasks:  
 
(i)  Assist  the  team  leader  and  wind  power  expert  in  identifying  an  appropriate 
framework for REDP Biomass Energy and Wind Power. 
(ii)  Undertake extensive analysis of relevant policies, regulations, incentive schemes, 
etc. to identify barriers to renewable energy development.  
(iii)  Assist the team leader and wind power expert in identifying benchmark standards 
and selection criteria for priority investment projects and pilot projects. 
(iv)  Prepare  economic  analysis  of  selected  priority  investment  projects  and  pilot 
projects. 
(v)  Assist team leader and other team members in the development of information 
brochures on various aspects of renewable energy development and energy 
conservation in rural areas. 
 
5.  Financial Analyst (1.5 person-months). The expert will assist the team leader and wind 
power expert. In particular, the expert will undertake the following tasks:  
 
(i)  Assist  the  team  leader  and  wind  power  expert  in  identifying  an  appropriate 
framework for REDP Biomass Energy and Wind Power.

Appendix 3  11 
(ii)  Undertake extensive analysis of relevant policies, regulations, incentive schemes, 
etc. to identify barriers to financing of renewable energy projects. 
(iii)  Assist the team leader and wind power expert in identifying benchmark standards 
and selection criteria for priority investment projects and pilot projects. 
(iv)  Analyze existing financing mechanisms; identify innovative financing tools and 
approaches to promote rural renewable energy development. 
(v)  Prepare  financial  analysis  of  selected  priority  investment  projects  and  pilot 
projects. 
(vi)  Assist team leader and other team members in the development of information 
brochures on various aspects of renewable energy development and energy 
conservation in rural areas. 
 
B.  National Consultants 
 
6.  A team of national consultants will supplement and support the international consultants 
with similar expertise. The national consultants will have extensive knowledge of renewable 
energy  development  in  Gansu  and  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  and  will  assist  the 
international consultants to quickly become familiar with their tasks by (i) reviewing relevant 
reports, analytical data, policies, regulations; and (ii) translating documents into English. The 
national consultant team will comprise   
 
(i)  two rural renewable energy specialists (6 person-months each),  
(ii)  wind power specialist (4 person-months),  
(iii)  energy economist (3 person-months),  
(iv)  financial analyst (4 person-months), 
(v)  environment analyst (3 person-months), and 
(vi)  social development specialist (4 person-months). 
 
7.  The  environment  analyst  and  social  development  specialist  will  ensure  that 
environmental and social safeguards are integrated into the pilot project design, and an initial 
assessment of priority  investment  projects is carried out in the prefeasibility studies. The 
environment analyst will prepare a categorization form and an environment evaluation report 
for selected pilot biomass energy projects. The social development expert will ensure that the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) safeguard policies for involuntary resettlement and indigenous 
people  (as  applicable)  are  considered  in  the  design  of  the  pilot  projects,  and  a  suitable 
categorization form and impact assessment reports shall be submitted to ADB for prior review 
before  the  implementation  of  the  pilot  projects.  The  social  development  expert  shall  also 
ensure that extensive consultations are held with affected persons and beneficiaries of pilot 
projects and that their views are addressed in the design. The social development expert will 
also assist the Implementing Agency in carrying out a public information campaign on the 
benefits of rural clean energy development.
